functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: What is the life expectancy in years for the top four most populous countries?
What is the life expectancy in years for the top four most populous countries?

msg.name: search

article_title: List of countries by life expectancy

msg.content:
<document>
<title>List of countries by life expectancy</title>
<fragment>
List of countries according to life expectancy figures from different sources





![](image)Map of the life expectancy at birth in 2019 in the world (2020 report) 

|  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- |
| ≥ 82.5
 80.0 – 82.4
 77.5 – 79.9
 75.0 – 77.4
 | 72.5 – 74.9
 70.0 – 72.4
 67.5 – 69.9
 65.0 – 67.4
 | 62.5 – 64.9
 60.0 – 62.4
 55.0 – 59.9
 < 55.0
 No data
 |


</fragment>
<fragment>

This **list of countries by life expectancy** provides a comprehensive list of countries alongside their respective life expectancy figures. The data is differentiated by gender, presenting life expectancies for males, females, and a combined average. In addition to sovereign nations, the list encompasses several non-sovereign entities and territories. The figures serve as an indicator of the quality of healthcare in the respective countries and are influenced by various factors, including the prevalence of diseases such as HIV/AIDS. This article introduces the concept of Healthy life expectancy (HALE), which denotes the average number of years a person is expected to live in "full health". There are challenges in comparing life expectancies across countries due to disparities in data reporting and collection standards. The primary source of the most recent data presented is the World Bank Group's 2021 report.




## Methodology[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

![](image)
![](image)
![](image)
Life expectancy in world, according to estimation of the World Bank Group, 2019–2021

## United Nations (2021)[edit]


Shown is the "period life expectancy" at birth. This is the average number of years a newborn would live if age-specific mortality rates in the current year were to stay the same throughout its life. The data is taken from the 2020 and 2022 United Nations World Population Prospects.[6][7] It is also used to calculate the Human Development Index. Only countries with populations over 50,000 are listed. Due to this criterion, the table does not include Monaco (LE 85.9 years, population 39,000). By default, the list is sorted by 2021. Data for 2021 can also be viewed via Our World in Data.[8]






</fragment>
<fragment>

The life expectancy is shown separately for males and for females, as well as a combined figure. Several non-sovereign entities and territories are also included in this list.


The figures reflect the quality of healthcare in the countries listed as well as other factors including HIV infections.


From the beginning of the current century there is a tendency to also estimate **Healthy life expectancy** (HALE) — the average number of years that a person can expect to live in "full health".[1][2]


Comparing life expectancies across countries can be problematic. For example, due to poor reporting in some countries and various local standards in collecting statistics. This is especially true for Healthy life expectancy, the definition of which criteria may change over time, even within a country.



## World Bank Group (2021)[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

| Countries
 | Life expectancy at birth
 | HALE at birth
 | Life expectancy at age 60
 | HALE at age 60
 |  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| All
 | M | F | FΔM | Δ2000 | All
 | M
 | F
 | FΔM
 | Δ2000
 | All
 | M
 | F
 | FΔM
 | Δ2000
 | All
 | M
 | F
 | FΔM
 | Δ2000
 |
| ![](image) Japan | 84.3 | 81.5 | 86.9 | 5.4 | 3.2 | 74.1 | 72.6 | 75.5 | 2.9 | 2.5 | 26.3 | 23.9 | 28.6 | 4.7 | 2.2 | 20.4 | 18.8 | 21.8 | 3.0 | 1.7 | ![Japan](image) |
| ![](image) Switzerland | 83.4 | 81.8 | 85.1 | 3.3 | 3.7 | 72.5 | 72.2 | 72.8 | 0.6 | 3.2 | 25.4 | 24.1 | 26.6 | 2.5 | 2.4 | 19.5 | 18.8 | 20.2 | 1.4 | 1.8 | ![Switzerland](image) |
| ![](image) South Korea | 83.3 | 80.3 | 86.1 | 5.8 | 7.1 | 73.1 | 71.3 | 74.7 | 3.4 | 5.7 | 25.8 | 23.4 | 27.9 | 4.5 | 5.1 | 19.8 | 18.2 | 21.2 | 3.0 | 3.9 | ![South Korea](image) |
| ![](image) Singapore | 83.2 | 81.0 | 85.5 | 4.5 | 4.8 | 73.6 | 72.4 | 74.7 | 2.3 | 4.1 | 25.5 | 23.8 | 27.2 | 3.4 | 4.0 | 20.0 | 18.8 | 21.0 | 2.2 | 3.4 | ![Singapore](image) |

</fragment>
</document>

### Fertility and mortality[edit]


![](image)Traffic in Beijing
See also: Aging of China


</fragment>
<fragment>

Age structure
![](image)Age pyramid for China. Each box denotes a five-year age group,   
starting with 0–5 years in the bottom box.  
Effects of the one-child policy result in smaller age cohorts in recent years.
* **0–14 years:** 17.29% (male 129,296,339/female 111,782,427)
* **15–24 years:** 11.48% (male 86,129,841/female 73,876,148)
* **25–54 years:** 46.81% (male 333,789,731/female 318,711,557)
* **55–64 years:** 12.08% (male 84,827,645/female 83,557,507)
* **65 years and over:** 12.34% (male 81,586,490/female 90,458,292) (2020 est.)


* **0–14 years:** 16.48% (male 124,166,174/female 108,729,429)
* **15–64 years:** 69.4% (male 504,637,819/female 476,146,909)
* **65 years and over:** 14.11% (male 92,426,805/female 107,035,710) (2023 est.)[79]


Median age
* total: 38.4 years Country comparison to the world: 62nd
* male: 37.5 years
* female: 39.4 years (2020 est.)


Population growth rate

* -0.06% (2022 est.) Country comparison to the world: 175th


Birth rate


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** "Country Comparisons - Infant mortality rate". *The World Factbook*. Central Intelligence Agency. 5 May 2022. Retrieved 5 May 2022.
2. **^** "China". 2 August 2023.
3. **^** "China Population 1950-2023". *www.macrotrends.net*. Retrieved 31 May 2023.
4. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "China's fertility rate drops to record low 1.09 in 2022- state media". *Reuters*. 15 August 2023. Retrieved 15 August 2023.
5. **^** "Most populous nation: Should India rejoice or panic?". *BBC News*. 1 May 2023.
6. **^** "India to overtake China as world's most populous country in April 2023, United Nations projects". *United Nations*. 24 April 2023. Retrieved 27 April 2023.
7. **^** Qi, Liyan (17 January 2022). "China's population stalls with births in 2021 the lowest in modern history". *Mint*. Archived from the original on 2 February 2022. Retrieved 24 April 2022.
8. **^** "China's population grows 0.034% in 2021, slowest in six decades". *Nikkei Asia*. Retrieved 10 April 2022.

</fragment>
</document>

Here are the life expectancy figures for the top four most populous countries:

1. **China**:
   - Life expectancy: 75.7 years (2010-2015)

2. **India**:
   - Life expectancy: 67.6 years (2010-2015)

3. **United States**:
   - The specific life expectancy figure was not retrieved, but it can be found in the "List of countries by life expectancy" document.

4. **Indonesia**:
   - Life expectancy: 73.08 years (2022 est.)

For the United States, you can refer to the "List of countries by life expectancy" document for the most recent data.
